title: Trial by Finder: how Fred Schebesta grew up
text:
A few metres away in the open-plan office, a faint hum emanates from a rack of servers mining for bitcoin. It’s a reminder of Finder’s diversified business model, comparing products across 105 categories, running a cryptocurrency exchange called HiveEx, preparing to launch a personal finance app, and ploughing profits into an internal venture capital arm in search of the next big thing.

Things used to be far cruder. Schebesta and Restuccia’s first business was called Freestyle Media and, in the internet wild west of the early 2000s, it lived up to its name, buying up all sorts of domain names on a bet that someone would one day be willing to pay for them. If you’d like to own christmasday.com.au, they’re still the guys to see.

They handed back anzacday.com.au when, as Schebesta recalls, broadcaster Alan Jones somehow found out they owned the sensitive domain and, after ranting about it on air, “people from the RSL started ringing our office complaining”.

Freestyle’s bread and butter was search engine optimisation (SEO): helping clients ensure their website appears on the first page of a Google search. As Schebesta admits, they would do so by almost any means necessary.

In 2005 Schebesta and Restuccia sold Freestyle for $1.36 million to ASX-listed media group Q Ltd.

Two years later the pair bankrolled Finder, with Schebesta in for 80 per cent and Restuccia 20 per cent. And the internet’s scrappy ethos lived on.

Even now, if Frank owes me three bucks I will make sure he pays it back. And I expect him to do the same with me. — Fred Schebesta

For its first few years, should you have clicked on a Finder link, there would be a good chance you’d encounter a time-wasting page that was heavy on SEO-friendly keywords and light on helpfulness. That page would then funnel you towards curated, commission-earning domains.

On the eve of the Google penalty in 2011, Finder was bent on winning the eyeballs of people researching credit cards, home loans and insurance online. To do so, it was not always relying on its researchers being better than those of incumbents such as Canstar and iSelect.

Advertisement

“We bought a few links that weren’t totally legit by today’s standards,” says Schebesta, his slight smile betraying the fact that Finder had taken every dirty trick he ever learnt in SEO and run with it.

“We knew what we were doing, and Google found out. And that’s not good.”

Fred Schebesta: "Every single bit of traffic we get today is thanks to the hard work of our people." James Brickwood

He doesn’t know if it was an algorithm or a Googler who flicked the switch that morning, and made Finder disappear. Regardless, he had little choice but to turn over a new leaf.

A plaque next to the samurai sword acknowledges the “tireless hours” spent removing dodgy links and researching new content that had, by June of that year, restored Finder’s rankings in Google searches to at least a semblance of their former selves. Instead of deploying tricks to attract traffic, Finder swivelled towards bona fide research into the products it describes and recommends.

“We bought finder.com to be the domain that everything would sit under from then on, and there was no way we were going to risk losing that,” Schebesta says.

“Every single bit of traffic we get today is thanks to the hard work of our people – someone’s willingness to stay talking to that call centre operator, and get the little intricacies. We’ll know the purchase rate versus the cash advance rate on a credit card, for instance, and that stuff’s not written anywhere.”

A year after it cut off Finder, Google launched its Penguin update which rendered most of Schebesta’s “spamdexing” methods useless. The internet had grown up, and so had he.

Schebesta had some experience at beating adversity before 2011. His childhood was an unusual mix of privilege and privation. Both he and Restuccia attended the expensive and academically selective Sydney Grammar School, yet Schebesta recalls living “super frugally” as his parents studied to be doctors.

Advertisement

“At one stage we were living in a caravan parked out the back of a little medical centre they’d built in Allambie Heights,” he says. “It was a little rough, and at the time I wished they’d hang out with me more. But on reflection it kind of ingrained in me what Finder is all about today – making the most out of what you have.”

The penny-pinching ethos behind the comparison site certainly comes from the top. As Schebesta started the SEO business, skipping computer science lectures at university because internet programming languages still weren’t being taught there, he would eat tinned spaghetti every day and patch holes in his shoes with gaffer tape. “Even now, if Frank owes me three bucks I will make sure he pays it back,” he says. “And I expect him to do the same with me.”

The inspiration for Finder itself was frugality. Close to the edge in every regard, Freestyle Media had been run on credit cards, and the pair became so passionate about getting the best deal – Schebesta once haggled with ANZ over 2¢ – they turned their hacks into a credit card blog which became Finder’s first comparison service.

Not that he’s a complete Scrooge. For the past six years Finder has laid on breakfast and lunch for its staff every day – although, as Schebesta can’t help admitting, the resulting gains in productivity have saved him money.

In 2018 he splurged on a $4 million apartment in Sydney’s beachside Tamarama (he has two daughters and a “great relationship” with his former wife), and names his hobby outside work as fine meals and long conversations at restaurants like Spice Temple and Bistro Papillon.

As comparison sites like Finder become bigger, they are attracting more attention. In April, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission took iSelect – a competitor to Finder – to court, alleging that while it told users it would recommend the best electricity or gas provider for their needs, in reality it was recommending energy plans from the companies which paid iSelect the most in commissions. iSelect listed in 2013 at $1.85 per share. Its share price is now sinking towards 50¢. For its part, Finder claims its comparisons and reviews are independent of any commissions it gets paid.

And for now, Schebesta is keeping his focus on building the business, without the distraction of trying to get it towards its own ASX listing.

“Finder is a real business and we intend on growing it privately,” he says. “If there is a clear reason to IPO, we will. Otherwise we aren’t looking to cash in quick, unlike some of those start-ups you’ve seen where the share price tanks on listing.”

Schebesta’s willingness to invest in himself came from his parents, specifically his mother, Kerrie Meades – one of the first women in NSW to become an ophthalmologist.

“When I was 20, I asked Mum for a new computer because I’d just been discovering this world of the internet. She went straight out and bought me this top-of-the-line model, which I built my first business on,” he says. “She used to say to me, ‘If you buy cheap, you buy twice. If you buy quality, you forget the cost.’”

The November issue of AFR Magazine, including the Young Rich List, is out on Friday, October 25 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
description: Finder now turns over $100 million a year, but when Google pulled the plug on it in 2011, co-founder Fred Schebesta had to turn over a new leaf.
